variant.question:

Obstacle Height: 310 ft   
Distance: 22000 ft   
OAT: 35ºC   
PA: 2140 ft   
HW: 20 kts   
PMC OFF   
Flaps 15º

Refer to figure.  
The annex shows an example of an RTOM chart for a medium jet aeroplane at a particular runway. In each chart box, the following information is provided for a given wind component, and a given outside air temperature: MTOM / limitation code / V**1**\-V**R**\-V**2**.

Using the conditions below, what are the limiting factor(s) for the combinations of take-off speeds and take-off mass?

OAT: 65ºC  
Headwind: +20 kt

Refer to figure or CAP698 file 4.6\.   
 Given the following information:

Runway 06   
 Airport Elevation: 1500 ft   
 QNH: 1013 hPa   
 OAT: +35°C   
 W/V: 060/12   
 Take-off configuration: Flaps 15   
 Tyre rating: 210 MPH   
 Power Management Computer (PMC): ON

Find the tyre speed limit take-off mass.

Refer to figure.

What are the take-off speeds for a balanced field take-off from an airport at 1 200 ft of elevation, runway 25 with 1% downwhill slope. The current weather conditions are: 07005kts 9999 BKN020 20/15 Q1003\. The expected take-off mass of the aircraft is 320 tonnes.

Refer to figure or to CAP 698 figure 4.31\.   
An MRJT (Medium Range Jet Transport) aircraft is performing circuits as part of pilot training. So far, 17.6 Million foot-pounds of energy have been absorbed by the brakes, and the pilots now want to make a final landing without any reverse thrust, which shall add a further 10 Million foot-pounds of energy. Which of the following is the best procedure to follow?

options.text: Land, then cool the brakes for no more than 80 minutes before the next take-off.
Fly around with the gear up for 30 minutes, then land.
Land as soon as required, there is no brake cooling requirement.
Fly around with the gear down for 6 minutes, then land. Park the aircraft for at least 60 minutes.

variant.question:
Refer to the figure or CAP 698 file 4.4.  
An MRJT aeroplane is scheduled to depart from an island airport and the crew is calculating the take-off performance with the following data:

Runway 03: TORA 7000 ft, slope 1% UP, 5 kt headwind component.  
Runway 21: TORA 7000 ft, slope 1 % DOWN, 5 kt tailwind component.  
Airport pressure altitude: 10 ft.  
Temperature: +21º C.

To maintain terrain clearance, taking off from runway 03 requires the use of flap 5, whereas runway 21 departs over the ocean, so flap 15 may be used. The planned take-off mass with desired fuel is currently 59 100 kg. After calculating the runway 03 take-off performance, the crew finds that the Field-Length-Limited Take-Off Mass (FLLTOM) is under the planned take-off mass at 58 500 kg. Which of the following options is best from both an airmanship and commercial standpoint?

options.text: Runway 03 should be chosen because a take-off into a headwind gives greater safety margins and 600 kg of fuel should be offloaded.
A departure from runway 21 is preferred, with a down-slope and tailwind, as this will increase safety margins in the event of stopping.
Runway 03 should be chosen as the headwind gives a better climb performance and 600 kg of baggage should be offloaded.
A departure from runway 21 is preferred as this allows for the FLLTOM to be increased by approximately 1000 kg.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.(For this question use CAP 698 Figure 4.7).  
Planned take-off mass is 64000 kg, pressure altitude 4000 ft, OAT +10ºC, V1 151, 155, 161\. Runway slope is -1% and tailwind 5 kt. What is the maximum permitted take-off mass?

The annex shows an example of an RTOM chart for a medium jet aeroplane at a particular runway. In each chart box, the following information is provided for a given wind component, and a given outside air temperature: MTOM / limitation code / V**1**\-V**R**\-V**2**. What is the meaning of the code 4/4?

Refer to figure or CAP698 file 4.23.  
The Medium Range Jet Transport aircraft is planned to operate a flight from Cyprus to central Europe. The highest MSA en-route is 12100 ft. Given the following conditions and assuming net performance, what would be the highest aircraft mass to sustain MSA following an engine failure?

OAT: ISA +14°C.  
Engine Anti-ice: OFF  
Wing Anti-ice: OFF  
A/C: AUTO (HIGH)

Refer to figure.

Find the time taken (I), the fuel used (II) and distance travelled (III) to stabilising height for an aircraft that experiences an engine failure at 41 000 ft with an all-up weight at the point of failure of 35 000 lb...

Refer to figure or CAP698 file 4.28.  
What is the minimum field length required for the worst wind situation, landing a twin jet aeroplane with the anti-skid inoperative?

Elevation: 2000 ft  
QNH: 1013 hPa  
Landing mass: 50000 kg  
Flaps: as required for minimum landing distance  
Runway condition: dry  
Wind: Maximum allowable tailwind: 15 kt  
Maximum allowable headwind: 50 kt

Refer to figure or CAP 698 file 4.6\.   
 Given the following information:

* Outside air temperature: 25°C
* Pressure altitude: 7 000 ft
* Tailwind component: 3 kt
* Flaps: 5°
* PMC: OFF

Find the FLAPS 5 TYRE SPEED LIMIT MASS for an aircraft which is fitted with 210 mph tyres.

Refer to figure or CAP698 file 4.31.  
An MRJT aeroplane is landing on runway 25 at an airport which has a long, dry runway with no performance restrictions. The runway has been chosen because of its negligible taxi distance after landing. The planned turnaround time is 25 minutes. Given the following information, is this turnaround time achievable?

Landing mass: 51 000 kg  
V**REF**: 132 kt  
Surface Wind: 070°/6 kt (use 50% of headwind component or 150% of tailwind component as applicable)  
Airfield Elevation: 280 ft  
QNH: 1013 hPa  
OAT: +19°C

options.text: No, reverse thrust cannot be used for credit during landing and most conservative braking must be accounted for, requiring an inspection of the fuse plugs after 30 minutes.
Yes, provided reverse #2 detent is used with any autobrake setting.
Yes, provided reverse #2 detent is used with autobrake #1 or #2.
No, reverse thrust cannot be used for credit during landing resulting in a minimum cooling time of approximately 60 minutes for the lowest autobrake settings #1 and #2.

variant.question:

For a twin engined turbojet in the cruise at M0.78, determine the hourly fuel flow at FL340 and a mass of 55000 kg.

Refer to figure.

A flight crew is preparing for a flight over a mountain range, and is looking at their cruise contingency planning in case of engine failure. With the following conditions, what is the one-engine-inoperative maximum cruise altitude?

Expected Gross Weight: 31 000 lb   
 Temperature: ISA + 5°C   
 Anti-ice: OFF

Given:

BRP: 3420 ft AMSL   
 Runway slope: 1.3% Downhill   
 TODR: 2760 m   
 Obstacle elevation: 3785 ft

Calculate the obstacle height above reference zero for the MRJT:

Refer to figure or CAP 698 figure 4.23\.   
 Given the following information:

Mass: 43 500 kg   
 OAT: ISA +10°C   
 Engine anti-ice: ON   
 Wing anti-ice: OFF   
 A/C: Auto (High)   
 Airport 1 pressure altitude: 24 000 ft   
 Airport 2 pressure altitude: 23 000 ft   
 Airport 3 pressure altitude: 20 000 ft   
 Airport 4 pressure altitude: 19 500 ft

Which two airports are the most appropriate for a pilot to choose for an approach and landing?

Refer to figure.

NOTE: For this question do NOT interpolate, Choose the most conservative figures at all times.

Given the following information and by using the chart provided, determine the aircraft's RTOM:

Runway: 23L   
 Wind: 230°/14 kt   
 OAT: +24ºC   
 QNH: 1025 hPa   
 Engine Anti-Ice: ON   
 Packs: OFF

Refer to figure or CAP 698 figure 4.4\.   
 Given the following:

* Runway 02, TORA 6 400 ft, 1% upslope, obstacle after departure, maximum 5º flaps allowed.
* Runway 20, TORA 6 400 ft, 1% downslope, departure over the sea, maximum 15º flaps allowed.
* Wind: 020° / 5 kt

The actual TOM is 58 800 kg, which is 600 kg beyond the limit for runway 02.

Which of the following options is the best choice, from both a safety and commercial standpoint?

options.text: Defuel by 600 kg and take-off on RWY 02.
Take-off on RWY 20, after reducing the TOM.
Take-off on RWY 20 despite tailwind, as useful load could be increased by 600 kg.
Offload 600 kg of passengers or bags and take-off on RWY 02.

Landing Mass: 45 000 kg   
 Tyre pressure: 200 psi

 Quick line up

An MRJT is scheduled to take-off from the Madrid–Barajas International Airport (LEMD). Given the following information below, determine the V1, VR and V2 take-off speeds.

Actual Take-Off Mass: 54 750 kg  
Airport Elevation: 1 998 ft  
Outside Air Temperature: +38°C  
Flaps Position: 15°  
Runway Slope: 0.2% Down  
Wind: 10 kt headwind

options.text: V1:131 kt, VR:133 kt and V2:140 kt
V1:138 kt, VR:140 kt and V2:146 kt
V1:134 kt, VR:134 kt and V2:140 kt
V1:139 kt, VR:140 kt and V2:146 kt

variant.question:
Refer to figure or use CAP 698 Figure 4.31.  
Determine the advised cooling schedule and minimum brake cooling time after landing for the following performance data:

Estimated landing mass: 90 000 lb  
VREF: 125 kt  
Corrections to VREF for landing speed: (VREF – 3 kt)  
Corrections to VREF for wind component: minus 50% of a headwind or plus 150% for a tailwind  
Headwind component: 4 kt  
Pressure Altitude: 2 000 ft  
OAT: + 10°C  
Braking configuration: Autobrake 2  
Reverse Thrust: Normal #2 Detent  
Taxi miles: 1 mile  
Add one million foot pounds for each taxi mile to obtain total energy.

options.text: Cooling Schedule II, cooling recommended, recommended 25 minutes ground cooling before take-off.
Cooling Schedule II, cooling recommended, recommended 16 minutes ground cooling before take-off.
Cooling Schedule II, cooling recommended, recommended 8 minutes ground cooling before take-off.
Cooling Schedule I normal, NO special cooling procedure required.

MTOM: 59 800 kg  
TOM: 50 850 kg  
Pressure Altitude: 1 980 ft  
Temperature: +38°C  
Headwind: 10 kt  
Flaps: 5º  
PMC: ON  
Slope: 0.1% downslope

Airport OAT: +35ºC  
Airport pressure altitude: 2 000 ft  
Flaps: 5º  
A/C pack: OFF.  
Anti-icing system OFF  
PMC: OFF

Refer to figure or use Cap 698 figure 4.5.

Find the climb-limited take off mass for a medium range jet transport (MRJT) aeroplane, given:

Airport OAT: 30ºC   
 Airport pressure altitude: 2 000 ft   
 Take off flap setting: Flap 15   
 A/C conditioning: Packs OFF

A Commercial flight is planned with a turbojet aeroplane to an aerodrome with a Landing Distance Available of 2400 m. The aeroplane mass must be such that on arrival the aeroplane can be landed within:

Refer to the figure or CAP 698 Figure 4.31.  
Due to a predictive wind shear warning, a take-off at Madrid airport is rejected. Using the data below, when can another take-off be attempted?  
  
Take-off mass: 61 300 kg  
Aerodrome elevation: 2 000 ft  
OAT: +34°C  
Wind: calm  
Speed at rejection: 80 kt

options.text: Cooling is recommended and it requires approximately 30 minutes when giving credit for reverse.
The fuse plugs may melt and the take-off must be delayed by approximately 40 minutes.
Cooling is recommended and it requires approximately 40 minutes when giving credit for reverse.
Cooling is recommended and it will require approximately 45 minutes to achieve this.

variant.question:
(Refer to figure or Performance Manual MRJT 1 Figure 4.24).   
 With regard to the drift down performance of the twin jet aeroplane, what is meant by "equivalent gross weight at engine failure"?

options.text: The increment accounts for the higher fuel flow at higher temperatures.
The equivalent gross weight at engine failure is the actual gross weight corrected for OAT higher than ISA +10° C.
This gross weight accounts for the lower Mach number at higher temperatures.
The increment represents fuel used before engine failure.

variant.question:

Temperature: 30°C  
Pressure Altitude: 6000 feet  
Take-Off Weight: 320 tons  
Downslope: 1%  
Wind: 5 knots tailwind

Determine the V1, VR and V2 speeds in the following conditions round the answers up to the nearest whole number

options.text: V1 \= 147 KIAS, VR \= 159 KIAS, and V2 \= 169 KIAS.
V1 \= 148 KIAS, VR \= 159 KIAS, and V2 \= 169 KIAS.
V1\= 144 KIAS, VR \= 156 KIAS, and V2 \= 166 KIAS.
V1 \= 144 KIAS, VR \= 160 KIAS, and V2 \= 170 KIAS.

variant.question:
Refer to figure or CAP 698 file 4.29.  
Given the following information, what is the Climb Limited Landing Mass?

Airport OAT: 0⁰C, icing conditions  
Airport Pressure Altitude: 4 000 ft  
Flap Position: 15⁰  
Air conditioning Packs: OFF  
Anti-Ice: Engine ON only

Refer to figure or CAP698 fig. 4.31.

The flight crew of an MRJT plan to touchdown with the braking configuration: Autobrake 2, Normal Reverse #2 Detent.   
 However, on touchdown, the thrust reverser fail light illuminates and the Commander cancels the reverse thrust and selects Autobrake 3 instead, to gain some extra braking. From the runway the aeroplane has to taxi 1.5 miles to the assigned terminal gate.   
 Given the following performance data, how much energy has been absorbed per brake unit, and what is the minimum brake cooling time after this landing?

Estimated landing mass: 100 000 lb   
 V**REF**: 123 kt   
 Corrections to V**REF**: (V**REF** \- 3kt)   
 Corrections to V**REF** for wind component: minus 50% of a headwind or plus 150% for a tailwind   
 Headwind component: 4 kt   
 Pressure Altitude: 5,000ft   
 OAT: -10°C   
 Add one million foot pounds for each taxi mile to obtain total brake energy.

options.text: Approximately 9.5 million foot-pounds of energy has been absorbed per brake, with an advised cooling time of 16 minutes.
Approximately 15.5 million foot-pounds of energy has been absorbed per brake, with an advised cooling time of at least of 52 minutes.
Approximately 14.5 million foot-pounds of energy has been absorbed per brake, with an advised cooling time of 44 minutes.
Approximately 18.5 million foot-pounds of energy has been absorbed per brake, with an advised cooling time of 62 minutes.

options.text: There is no effect of the wind on the climb angle relative to the ground.
The effect of the wind must be taken from another chart.
The limitation presented in this chart is taken relative to air.
There is a built-in safety measure.

variant.question:

Given the information provided below, the pilot of a jet-engine aircraft must determine which of following en-route alternate airports are the most appropriate diversion airports in case of an engine failure during the cruise phase.

Refer to figure or to CAP 698 Figure 4.31\.   
 A pilot is instructed to reject their take-off whilst departing from Madrid airport in the MRJT (Medium-Range Jet Transport). Using the data below, when will the brakes have cooled sufficiently for another take-off to be commenced?

Actual take-off mass: 56 000 kg   
 Aerodrome Elevation: 1998 ft   
 OAT: +34º C   
 CAS at rejection: 70 kt   
 Ground speed at rejection: 65 kt

options.text: Immediately, as no brake cooling is required.

variant.question: With regard to the take-off performance of a twin jet aeroplane, why does the take-off performance climb limit graph show a kink at 30°C, pressure altitude 0?

options.text: At higher temperatures the flat rated engines determines the climb limit mass
The engines are pressure limited at lower temperature, at higher temperatures they are temperature limited
At lower temperatures one has to take the danger of icing into account
At higher temperatures the VMBE determines the climb limit mass

variant.question:
